history.content:
I made it public, thank you for the question.

The subproblem definition in words should just look at the minimum cost, it doesn't involve the depth.

And for the recurrence think about what we did for chain matrix multiply.  Try all the options for the root

and then "look up" the min cost for the left and right subtrees.  The depth of everything in the left and 

right subtrees went up by +1, that's all you need to know to figure out the additional cost.  Got it now?  --Eric

children.subject: In terms of computing cost, I think at a given root, the cost is the sum of the costs of the subtrees plus the sum of the probabilities of all the elements in the current tree (with root = given root). If that helps? Just another way to look at it (as opposed to depth increasing by 1)

Thanks for the suggestion, maybe I  am missing the formula I can't get the math to work.

On another note, after watching CMM again,  I think I see the depth now using the row/column in my table.

Kris, To see what Kate is saying you might try a small example with say 4 words.  First, look at the expected cost for the best tree with just nodes 2,3 vs. a tree with all 4 words where nodes 2 and 3 are the left subtree.  The extra cost for putting this tree of nodes 2,3 one level down is just at the root you have 1 extra comparison -- what's the expected cost of that?

At a given root, "the cost is the sum of the costs of the subtrees plus the sum of the probabilities of all the elements in the current tree". The sum of the probabilities of all frequencies between i and j was tricky (to me anyways).

For anyone who did not follow, what happens is when you add the costs of left and right subtrees, p_k (being at the root), will be only counted once, however, p_{k-1} and p_{k+1} will necessarily be counted again. So you're left with something like

1 * p_k + 2 * (p_{k-1} + p_{k+1} + ... ) + ...

which attains the desired solution.

Pedro

Thanks for the explanations.  It finally clicked.

I worked through the math again for "the cost is the sum of the costs of the subtrees plus the sum of the probabilities of all the elements in the current tree" and it worked out correctly.    

However, I don't think i could have worked that formula myself.    After thinking about it, it makes sense,  I can work it out now that I had the answer.

Appreciate the help.
I think I'm going in the right direction, but when i work the cost for a simple example tree the math doesn't work out for me.

history.content:
I think I'm going down the right path to solve the problem.  I can break it into sub-problems and I have a recurrence formula which relies on the depth of the current node.   I'm struggling to get the depth into the sub-problems.

Splitting the problem up into left and right sub-trees and then trying to calculate the best cost of each.  The only way I can figure to get it into the sub-problems is to add a variable to track the max depth and also solve for all values of depth.

I can make this public if it's acceptable.
history.subject: Problem 6.20 Optimal BST - approach
